Award.AbstractNarration:
A request is made to fund new and replacement instrumentation on the R/V Atlantic Explorer, a 168? general purpose research vessel owned and operated by Bermuda Institute of Ocean Science (BIOS) as part of the University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System. BIOS is a U.S. 501 (c) 3 and 509 (a) not-for profit research and educational institution incorporated in the state of New York, and geographically located on the island of Bermuda. The mission of the ship is to support funded science research throughout the Central Atlantic but specifically work in support of the BATS program. RV Atlantic Explorer had 177 days funded in 2014, all but 10 of which (95%) were for NSF. In 2015, the vessel is scheduled to sail 157 days with 119 (76%) of them funded by NSF. With this proposal, BIOS provides technical descriptions and rationale for the acquisition of the following Oceanographic Instrumentation:

1) Niskin Water Samplers $25,000
2) Lab flow-through Sensors $29,553
3) Attitude determination unit for ADCP $16,225
4) Pyranometers (2 ea) $5,600
5) Sensor suite for forward mast $7,000
$83,378
Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 13-589). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
2015 Oceanographic Instrumentation R/V Atlantic Explorer

Final Project Report: OCE 1527000

This award, in the amount of $41,225 was used to purchase the instrumentation and equipment for required for upgrading the scientific capabilities of the R/V Atlantic Explorer. The R/V Atlantic Explorer is a 170 ft. general purpose oceanographic research vessel operated by Bermuda Institute of Ocean Sciences (BIOS) as part of the University­National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS) research fleet.

The Bermuda Institute of Ocean Sciences (BIOS) is a U.S. 501 (c) 3 and 509 (a) not­for profit research and educational institution incorporated in the state of New York, and geographically located on the island of Bermuda. The overarching mission of the R/V Atlantic Explorer is to provide a reliable and capable platform from which to accomplish cutting-edge ocean science, primarily funded by the National Science Foundation.

With this award, BIOS acquired the following Oceanographic Instrumentation Equipment:

1) Ocean Test Equipment External Spring Water Samplers: $25,000

A full set of Ocean Test Equipment External Spring Water Samplers were purchased and placed into service in January 2016. These new water samplers are a core component of the R/V Atlantic Explorer’s shared-use CTD system. This CTD system is comprised of ocean measuring instruments and water sampling bottles attached to a frame; together this system is the workhorse of oceanographic research. The CTD instrument package is regularly lowered to the bottom of the ocean, providing real-time physical, chemical, biological, and optical properties of the subsea environment to researchers aboard the vessel. This real-time data provides a comprehensive level of interaction to the researchers aboard the vessel. It allows the researchers to visualize and quantify the dynamics of the ocean and precisely extract sea-water samples from specific features of interest. The water samplers (a.k.a “Niskins bottles”) are a critical component of the system because they are the components that actually collect the distinct water samples from the deep-ocean, protect them from contamination and transport them to the deck of research vessel where further analysis can be performed by the researchers. The water samplers funded through this award have collected water samples from the the deep Atlantic Ocean during over 300 CTD deployment since they were put into service. Proper maintenance and care should keep these water samplers in operation supporting ocean researcher for years to come.               

This award provided a set of 30 Ocean Test Equipment manufactured external spring water samplers and have proven to be an important and reliable data producer and will continue to support the demands of many NSF funded ocean research projects in the future.

2) Ashtec ADU800 Attitude Determination Unit: $16,225

An Ashtec ADU800 Attitude Determination Unit was purchased, and installed and configured aboard the R/V Atlantic Explorer during the January 2016 shipyard visit. The new ADU800 replaced an outdated and non-supported ADU5 Attitude Determination Unit. The new unit was installed in the same location and the antennas array was modified to provide better geometry and alignment with the ship. This unit provides measurements of the ship’s attitude to the ship’s 75kHz ADCP system and is critical in providing quality ocean current data which can be accurately translated into true velocity relative to the Earth. This system supports the critical need for ocean current determination which is used in most NSF funded research projects.

This award provided a modern and accurate attitude determination unit and has successfully provided critical attitude and heading correction data to the ADCP system aboard the R/V Atlantic Explorer during 2016 and will continue to provide quality data for future projects.

TOTAL AWARD $41,225

Broader Impacts:

The principal impact of the present proposal is under criterion two, providing infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared­use instrumentation and laboratory spaces in support of their NSF­funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared­use instrumentation and laboratory infrastructure allows NSF­funded researchers from any US university or lab access to safely and efficiently conduct their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.
